title: 114_hr902
content: The Act may be cited as the "Earned Income Tax Credit Improvement and Simplification Act 2015" and includes a table of contents. Certain improvements in the earned income tax credit made permanent, strengthening the credit for individuals with no qualifying children, allowing credit in case of certain separated spouses, and eliminating the disqualified investment income test. SEC. 2. Certain improvements in the earned income tax credit made permanent, including an increase in the credit percentage for three or more qualifying children. The earned income tax credit percentage varies based on the number of qualifying children, with higher percentages for more children. For an eligible individual, the credit percentage ranges from 7.65% with no qualifying children to 45% with three or more qualifying children. The phaseout percentage also varies, with the highest being 21.06% for two or more qualifying children. The marriage penalty reduction is now permanent, with a $5,000 increase in the phaseout amount for joint returns filed by eligible individuals and their spouses. This amount will be adjusted for inflation after 2014. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act. Section 32(b) of the Code is amended by removing paragraph (3). Rounding rules apply after considering any increase in the cost of living adjustment for the taxable year. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being strengthened for individuals with no qualifying children. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being expanded to include individuals over 21 who are not full-time students and do not have qualifying children. The text discusses exceptions to eligibility criteria for the Earned Income Tax Credit, specifically regarding full-time student status and information return matching procedures for verifying claims under section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit percentage and phaseout percentage. The earned income amount and phaseout amount are also adjusted. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit percentage and phaseout percentage, as well as adjust the earned income amount and phaseout amount. The $10,425 amount in subsection (b)(2)(A) is updated to reflect 'calendar year 2012' instead of 'calendar year 1992'. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act. Taxpayers can receive a credit for individuals with no qualifying children if the children do not have valid social security numbers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow eligible individuals with no qualifying children to still be considered for the tax credit if their children are not taken into account for any other child tax benefit. The amendment applies to individuals without a qualifying child for taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. SEC. 5. Credit allowed for certain separated spouses without a qualifying child for taxable years starting after December 31, 2014. Section 32(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a special rule for separated spouses without a qualifying child for tax purposes. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act for separated spouses without a qualifying child for tax purposes. Taxpayers can claim a tax credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. Taxpayers may be eligible for a tax credit without a qualifying child if the child is claimed by another family member. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, allowing eligible individuals without a qualifying child to be treated as such for tax purposes. SEC. 7 eliminates the disqualified investment income test in Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Conforming amendments are made to related sections. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
